Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2008 01:28AM AimeeFaye wrote: Greetings Mable:  I started on the Tamoxifen on the 20th and have been "resting" 15 hours in a row ever since...wish I HAD a recliner!  I intend to do a full med review with my general practitioner and than another with my oncologist on Jan 23 (the first time I can see her).  I am dumb founded by how many and which of the drugs we need to use have side effects that leave us so exhausted...chemo was tiresome, but now that I am no longer doing chemo, I had hoped for a a gradual increase in energy....NOT.  I'll be following your update to see what magic you come up with...good luck, Debra
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen Mabledw Mabledw

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2008 09:57PM AimeeFaye wrote: Greetings Sunny:  What a kick in the gutt!  But there is hope!  And, when I read your post I felt like I was looking in the mirror!  I too have mets to the liver and am going into round 3 chemo using taxotere and xeloda or capcitabine.  (I had an mri last Friday, and get the results this Friday which is also round 3 chemo day. How many rounds have you had?  And in preparation for possibly challenging news, I am gathering strength by coming here, knowing that others have found options!  As chemo is my first line of defense (plan A)  I plan to ask my onco what her Plan B might look like!  I live in a really remote area travelling 4.5 hours one way for chemo, but I have shook up some bushes to find some complimentary services while on chemo. I access the services of a reputable doctor of chinese medicine and found a holistic healer.  I truly "like" both people.  (My extended family is still smirking but at least they're smiling!)  I also found much hope after reading "The Journey" by Brandon Bays.  Bernie Siegel and Larry Dossey have penned some historic material that is easy to read.  Hmmm...I think I'll google "stage IV BC, hope."  I haven't post in a while, but I know coming here brings much hope!  I know there are always options that make our lives better, we just don't always know what they are...but coming here is a good place to start!   You're included in my prayers...and I LOVE your name..."Sunny." Hugs to you, Deb
Posts.Title: Here we go again sunny365 sunny365

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2008 01:00AM AimeeFaye wrote: Greetings Sunny:  just back from round three and the blister on my left big toe from my new shoes is my biggest concern today...well, maybe the buzzed feeling from the steroids is a little annoying, but I have enough energy to do things I love doing.  I spoke with my onco about the MRI results, likely a stroke from some time ago (hmmmm I am 48 when could that have happened...oh well, we'll deal with that later.)  My capcetibine was reduced from 4 tables twice a day to three tabs twice a day.  My hands and feet were experiencing pins and needles, burning and skin breakdown despite an elaborate solution of vasoline and everything else that was slimy.  I slept in socks and gloves for the past two weeks and that helped, but my kind baker friend declared "use lard, if makes my hands baby butt soft."  So I sent my 21 year old son to the grocery for lard.  He came back with unsalted butter.  We'll try again.  Tonight I am wearing oxynol!  I saled through round one with one a day or two of exhaustion.  Some diarhea, liking bland foods, drinking LOTS of water....a glass every waking hour.  I worked with a BodyTalk practitioner twice, a holistic healer just started, hired a phsychotherpist to deal with the head games, replace my social worker who comes with the Cancer Center, found a medicine man and have now had two appointments with a Homeopath certified in China and Canada (whatever that means) but you in reknown in our region.  He's adjusted the prescription too for this go around cause I was REALLY sad after round two.  But while that may have been the chemo, it was likely also that my 18 year old daughter left home for collegue.  Boo Hoo.  My last discussion with my onco left me understanding that "if you are uncomfortable with the side effects we can try treating those or we can reduce of change drugs, but I am very hopeful with the taxotere alone...they are lots of options."  That was the most caring and compassionate piece of hope for me to hear.  THERE ARE ALWAYS OPTIONS. Unlike some of the women here, I am on leave from work.  I couldn't imagine standing up for more than an hour or two, and I really have "chemo brain," but stickee notes do well, and I'd like to believe that this is my repreave from superwoman multitasker time!  I wish you well with your treatment.  Share your thoughts with your medical team and enjoy that first wedding anniversary.  My husband and I celebrated our 28th on the telephone as I was on my was home from the MRI that day!  Just an aside:  I have also insisted that my potassium and magnesium levels by watched more closely. I also have diabetese and high blood pressure, so some of the componds my healthstyle plan.  I have broke the bank and order a food blender/with the motor of a lawn mower, so I plan to rethink all my eating patterns and needs.  I am not a vegie fan, but i can do vegie soups and mushy vegie things.  I'd been told to stay away from coffee and all soy products and introduced raw nuts and took out much meat.  I hear about awesome diet programs with much success, but my first line of therapyare the big guns (chemo, etc.) and have added the complimentary pieces as I find them...or they find my.  Brandon Bays writes a remarkable book, THe Journey and there is a form of healing called "Theta Therapy."  that has suppored some people's needs. And if you hear of options I'd appreciate hearing about it.  I absolutely know that the power of hope is indeed the more critical piece of all of this and there and books to read and women here to talk to.  Let's keep in touch sunny....from one woman recovering from mets to another....yes, I head people say they can't cure mets, yet, but, hmmmm, maybe the patient can somehow contribute too!!! Best to you and HAPPY 1St...and MANY MANY MORE, Deb
Posts.Title: Here we go again sunny365 sunny365

Posts.Content: AimeeFaye wrote: OK, this is a really benign and vane concern:  I CAN'T SMILE cause the sides of my mouth have been cracked for (oh, wow) over six weeks?  I've tried some over the counter products and searched for options but must ask the question here!  Seems so trite, but I really want to open my mouth wide to EAT AND I want to smile without cracking my face.  OK, maybe there is some humor here?  Anybody else been there and found a solution??? THANKS, Debra Aimeefaye Dx 4/25/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 2, 12/16 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Cracked smile????? AimeeFaye badboob67

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 09:03PM AimeeFaye wrote: Wow LuAnn...when it rains it pours!  And you and your grandkids and son don't deserve this!  The shock of dealing with your DIL and her father is enough to scare anyone, but you protected yourself...good for ya!  And your son will find a way through this difficult time, and he'll know he has your support...how lucky for him and his children.  About the tumor markers, they aren't at all used by my doctor, but I do understand the fear...and when there is chaos that we can't control around us (like your DIL's choice) we can feel overwhelmed and everything else is than suspect.  I am impressed that you have such a good medical team and that you are so knowledgable and know what questions to ask.  Be good to yourself through this and take joy in your son's return.  We are all thinking of you, and count you as a real blessing here...venting or not!  (((((Debra M.)))))
Posts.Title: Frustrated and Blue LuAnnH Isabella4

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2008 04:08AM AimeeFaye wrote: Greetings Stephanie:  I am interested in your doctor's choice of pain meds, but can you tell us what pain you have been experiencing: where, when, severity, etc.  I appreciate your sharing, Debra

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 02:32AM AimeeFaye wrote: Great news on the MRI Steph and yes, Pee, the waiting is dreadful.  BUT..I've learned something here tonight...get the the results BEFORE you see the oncologist.  In the past I just "lucked out" by talking to my general practitioner (I'm from Canada) but having the info before hand makes SO much more sense...you can deal with the type of news and use the time with the onco productively.  I SO appreciate this website and the women who post! Debra M.
Posts.Title: Had all of my scans...now the waiting game. pee AimeeFaye

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2009 06:14PM - edited Jan 21, 2009 06:17PM by AimeeFaye Louise: you go girl!  I have bone mets in my left hip and shoulder and continue to use a recumbant bike on a daily basis.  THe treadmill irritates these areas sometimes, so I only use it three or four times a week.  As long as my doc is pretty sure it won't cause any damage...away I go!   And I too have read that exercise during chemo is off benefit and the chemo's effacacy increases.  THey don't know why.  And besides...exercising makes me feel alive so I will continue to do it until my body screams stop.  I really wonder how much research is being done to support the larger needs of women with stage IV bc?  There is keen interest in the medical end, but many of the other areas seem to be unaddressed.  Or I just haven't found those studies yet.  Good luck with your exercising...hope it brings you joy! Debra M. PS...I am envious of those with access to pools...what a wonderful way to stretch and build your body!  (I live in rural isolated part of the world....but I like my bathtub!) pss  I also can't wait to start yoga...it SEEMS pleasant enough!

Debra M.

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2009 05:56PM AimeeFaye wrote: Greetings Cathy:  sorry to hear that you are in pain and missing out on really important sleep.  PLEASE know that we do not have to live with pain.  There ARE medications that can be sourced to deal with chronic and breakthrough pain.  A pain management specialist or pain centre are sources of some of the best info, and in Canada (where I live) we need a referral from our family physician.  Sometimes our family docs have some experience with managing some types of pain, and my oncologist offers radiation if and when I think I want to use it.  I, personally, have been able to manage the pain from a mastectomy and through chemo by using hydromorphone as it seems to be my doc's favorite med right now.  Caution about using heat especially if you have had lymph nodes removed...I was using a hot pad on my lower back and kept my body temp up enough to have my arm start to swell with lymphodena.  GREAT...one more thing to have to manage...but it is not insurmountable.  Good luck as you explore this new world of pain management...I look foward to hearing what works for you,  Hugs and best wishes, Debra M
Posts.Title: pain can't sleep cathy50 flyrzfan

Posts.Content: AimeeFaye wrote: Doesn't having cancer increase one's level of anxiety?!?!  After only two rounds of chemo and having had an mri last Friday, I get the results this Friday and have round 3 of chemo.  What a lucky girl....?!?!?  I keep visualizing doing the "happy happy joy joy dance" on Friday after my mri results.  And than I spent this evening here and on the net coming up with plan b,c and d.   I have NO idea what to expect after so short a treatment time...I am such a newbee to this process and haven't been here for a while cause I was really exhausted, achy and sad right after round two and for the first 10 days.  Round one...only a couple days of dread, round two, depressed, mouth sores, losing feeling in hands and feet, achy like fluy all over AND my daughter left for college (I was oh so sad but glad to see her doing life as she should at 18) and my son decided not to return to university cause he wanted to "be here to help" (I was oh so sad cause I don't want him to have to help....) but I am learning that "the new reality" (after cancer) is different!  I can't believe the head games that go on with this disease...."how long...what if...if only....I want..." And too few people to process this with.   Ugggghhhh.  Its waiting for results that increase my angst.  It will be a Loooonnnngggg 4.5 hour drive tomorrow to the city to see a psychologist (who I think I will say fairwell to tomorrow cause what we're doing together ain't helpin), and than a full Friday at the Cancer Center.  I have GOT to find something else to look forward to!  Hmmmm....maybe some chocolate pudding?  I'm asking for prayers ladies.... they sustain me! Deb Aimeefaye Dx 4/25/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 2, 12/16 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: First mri results Friday...prayers please AimeeFaye AimeeFaye

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2008 04:15AM AimeeFaye wrote: Thank you everyone for your prayers!   Sometimes I feel silly coming here asking for something so profound as a prayer from a stranger, but they really sustained me.  And I like Ativan!  Yep, an hour before we saw the onco I 'd had enough.  I was chattering like a chipmunk, telling jokes to my new social worker and working myself into exhaustion.  I was also having chemo the same day so the steroids had me wound WAY up.  So...adivan.  And the news from the onco was ok.  Seems the MRI was ONLY on my head (a whole hour in that machine...what did they find?) but they think the grey sploth (my words not their's) is likely a stroke.  Stroke?  Since when?  They''ve also discovered I have some heart put issues, so now we're all caucious about my potassium and magnesium levels.  Sheesh.  But, we do have back up plans.  The CT scan happend in two weeks so THAN I will know if the Taxoter and Xeloda are doing their thing.  I also got to see my Chinese homeopath who said "we not touch the liver, they do that, we keep the rest of the body healthy to help the chemo."  Love that man.  And I got to see my psychologist and I am starting to get this "Self regulation therapy," AND I spent some time with a wholistic healer, and got my wig trimmed. And I'm still running around like the energizer bunny...tomorrow may be REALLY quiet.  And my husband and I bought a motor home.  Did I say we did all this in an evening and two days?  Done.  I NEEDED something to look forward to so with all my doc's etc. blessing, my son and I will hit the road for a little better than a week, go see where my daughter is REALLY going to school, see another pracitioner or two along the way and if someone suggests I should stand on my head to get well, I'll do that too!!  I am not gullable, we have done extensive research on some of this stuff, but since I am away on leave (even my g.p. was morrose (sp?) and put me on leave) I have some time to research and lots of friends now asking if I had considered.... So, there are some diet changes pending, added liquid vitamins, stillw waiting for blood tests to see if Slow K is upping my potassium, and am going to learn to make wheat grass juice.  Yum?  AND, when I think I'm going to explode, I've got 1 mg of slow release adivan....and some hydromorphone to manage any pain (still mastectomy post op a lttle cranky).  And as you can tell, I am tired but NOT SAD...  Thanks to having plans and smart and compassionate people to share with...   Thanks to you all Deb
Posts.Title: First mri results Friday...prayers please AimeeFaye AimeeFaye

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2009 12:48AM AimeeFaye wrote: Hi Robin!  I appreciate your comments.  For a better part of today I've been saying to myself "nope, not now...we aren't going there now."  I seem to have to ACTIVELY decide NOT to think about cancer.  Sometimes I think I am OCD...at least the obsessive part!  I took the well deserved shove and decided to get my infusion today (a two hour load of pamidronate for bones at the E department of the local hospital) and do it with as much of an "up" as I could muster.  I slept through the non-event, went home and made myself some lunch (I think) and got totally engrossed in the swearing in of the President.  (I am one of those Canadians who should have been allowed to vote cause I followed the whole process through the years!)  I did not let cancer interrupt my enjoyment!!!  AND, I booked the travel, hotel, etc. plans for a week away and my son convinced my husband to join us!  And so we can now go away as a familiy and have a bang up time...at least that's the plan now!  I don't think the black fog has lift for me but I am pushing my way out of it.  I don't really know when one decides to use antidepressants...but I am getting awfully close.  I'll run this by my oncologist on Friday.  I gather one is able to switch from one drug to another with little complications.  I guess I need to have a heart to heart with my social worker and doc.  THANKS so much for your time and support. I plan to be feeling better asap. Debra M. ps  if there a disproportionately high number of Debs in these threads??? :)
Posts.Title: Emotional Yo Yo.... AimeeFaye barbe1958

Posts.Content: AimeeFaye wrote: I thought I had come out of this black hole....that was a few weeks ago, but I am trying to set op some simple travel plans for my two kids and myself and I am a wreck!  I have stable liver mets as of November, and finished chemo before Christmas.  Started tamoxifen.  Have had "twinges" in the area of the liver since before Christmas and with those feelings just start feeling overwhelmed.  Next ct scan is at the end of February, next appointment with the onc is at the end of the week.  I am UP and than I'm down...I just need to hear how others stay in the here and now and not get caught in the worry this fri(^^()n disease can muster.  I am planning this short trip to create some "adult" memories with my 21 and 18 year old kids....and than grieve cause....well, you all know this story.  How do we get up again?  Sorry....just having a bad evening and needing a hand up, Debra M. Aimeefaye Dx 4/25/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 2, 12/16 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Emotional Yo Yo.... AimeeFaye barbe1958

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2008 06:55AM - edited Sep 4, 2008 06:56AM by AimeeFaye Greetings Hopeful101:  I can almost imagine how frustrated, scared, and confused you, your mom and family must feel.  I am not a doctor, nor an onco, just a cancer patient who's been there....The day I was diagnosed my onco said "this is what I would recommend."  I asked her "why do you think this."  When she said "my experience guides me."  I asked how I get a second opinion. (I live in Canada so the rules of the game are a bit different.) I opted to have her present to her peers and went with that second opinion because it built on her recommendation.  But what reallly led me was my gut!  I know that sounds less than scientific, but everything I have read since says "if you don't FEEL good with the first or second opinion, get a third" and "oncologists are making educated decisions, but few two will present the same options even to two patients who look exactly the same."  Wow...doesn't that make it even more confusing? I have been told NOT to compare my treatment plan with someone with a similiar health profile.  The bottom line for me is: if it ain't working, can we change it? When and how do we decide if it's working, and what are the other options."  Your absolute best ally is your "total hope and faith!"  I'll keep you and your family in my prayers, Hugggs, Deb
Posts.Title: Confused!! Hopeful101 LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2008 04:58PM AimeeFaye wrote: Hi Nico!  I was just surfing the posts and came across your comment about your Chillow.  I googled the product but wonder if you can tell me how YOU use it?  I'm always on the look out for something to make this chemo process easier... thanks, Deb
Posts.Title: More Tips (and a Shopping List) for Getting Through Chemo rock MinusTwo

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2009 06:23PM AimeeFaye wrote: Ladies: thank you to each and every one of you for taking the time to answer my post.  Knowing that other women have experienced this makes it easier!  Janis: thanks for the kind words and honest truth. I have directed myself to not think about cancer or read or write about it on certain days, sometimes for shorter periods....I sometimes have to PLAN to not include cancer and deliberate living as part of the day.  I am also looking at whether or not to use anti depressants.  My doc wants me to try Effexor, but I am worried it will have me in an emotional limbo-land or a fog.  Do you know if that is a realistic concern?  I'd be interested in hearing your experience. Ladies: I REALLY appreciate you taking the time to share your experiences.  I honestly benefit from a gentle or even a swift "get on with living and $crew cancer!" comment....it DOES help!  I share the belief that health and survival is very much based on our mental ability to go on, though that does NOT equate to anyone "failing" when cancer gets the best of them.  And up until Christmas and starting Tamoxifen, I was able to achnowledge the "glass half full"....even through out chemo...so I guess I am wondering what triggered the most recent "bottom outs."  I DID find another thread with similar concerns...so I need to keep talking to others and benefiting from their experiences.  And I know its a downer subject, but thanks again for your help....all of you!  Blessing and hugs, Debra M.
